protocol.name: Ketamine Infusion Therapy for Treatment-Resistant Depression
protocol.overview: Evidence-based ketamine infusion protocol for treatment-resistant depression. Uses sub-anesthetic doses of intravenous ketamine (0.5 mg/kg) administered over 40 minutes in a monitored clinical setting. Based on extensive research demonstrating rapid antidepressant effects, often within hours to days.
evidence_sources: Zarate CA, et al. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2006;63(8):856-864 (PMID: 16894061)
Murrough JW, et al. Am J Psychiatry. 2013;170(10):1134-1142 (PMID: 23982301)
Wilkinson ST, et al. Am J Psychiatry. 2018;175(1):43-50 (PMID: 28969441)
Feder A, et al. JAMA Psychiatry. 2021;78(5):478-486 (PMID: 33533876)
American Psychiatric Association Guidelines on Ketamine for Depression
Consensus Statement on Ketamine in Mood Disorders (2017)

steps.title: Comprehensive Psychiatric Evaluation
steps.description: Detailed psychiatric assessment to confirm treatment-resistant depression, assess severity, evaluate prior treatment history, and determine appropriateness for ketamine therapy.
clinical_scales: Patient Health Questionnaire-15 (PHQ-15) for somatic symptoms

diagnostic_criteria.trd_criteria: Failed at least 2 adequate antidepressant trials in current episode

psychiatric_history: Detailed depression history (onset, course, prior episodes)
Complete medication history with specific agents, doses, durations, responses
Suicide attempt history and current suicidal ideation
Comorbid psychiatric diagnoses (anxiety, PTSD, OCD, etc.)
Substance use history (critical for ketamine - abuse potential)
Prior response to ketamine or other psychedelics
treatment_resistance_documentation: List of all antidepressant trials with adequacy assessment
Response to other treatments (ECT, TMS, etc.)

steps.title: Medical Clearance & Cardiovascular Assessment
steps.description: Comprehensive medical evaluation with emphasis on cardiovascular health, as ketamine increases blood pressure and heart rate. Essential safety screening before ketamine administration.

critical_parameters.baseline_bp: Must be <140/90 mmHg (uncontrolled hypertension is contraindication)
critical_parameters.baseline_hr: Must be 50-100 bpm (evaluate if outside range)

lab_tests_required: Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP) - especially liver and kidney function
Urine drug screen (assess for substance use)
Pregnancy test (for women of childbearing potential)

risk_stratification: Intracranial mass or increased intracranial pressure

other_medical_screening: Urological issues (ketamine can cause cystitis with chronic use)

steps.title: Substance Use & Abuse Potential Assessment
steps.description: Thorough evaluation of substance use history and abuse potential, given ketamine's dissociative properties and potential for misuse. Critical for patient selection and risk mitigation.

substance_use_history: Recovery status and duration of sobriety
risk_assessment: Motivation for ketamine treatment (seeking therapeutic effect vs. dissociative high)

risk_mitigation_strategies: Structured protocol with limited take-home options

steps.title: Eligibility Determination & Route Selection
steps.description: Evaluate all screening data to determine patient eligibility for ketamine therapy and select optimal administration route (IV vs. intranasal vs. oral).

absolute_contraindications.rationale: Ketamine increases BP acutely; risk of hypertensive crisis

absolute_contraindications.criteria: MI, stroke, or unstable angina within 6 months
absolute_contraindications.rationale: Cardiovascular stress from ketamine too risky

absolute_contraindications.criteria: Diagnosis of schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder

relative_contraindications.management: Close BP monitoring, ensure medications optimized, may proceed with caution
Ensure mood stabilizer on board, monitor for mania, may proceed with caution
Enhanced monitoring, treatment agreement, support person involvement
Careful consideration, may worsen dissociation, proceed only if benefits outweigh risks

intravenous_infusion.indications: Gold standard, most evidence, best for acute treatment, controlled dosing
intravenous_infusion.typical_protocol: 0.5 mg/kg over 40 minutes, 2-3 times per week for 2-4 weeks

intranasal_esketamine.indications: FDA-approved for TRD (Spravato), convenient, no IV needed
intranasal_esketamine.typical_protocol: 56-84 mg intranasally twice weekly, requires 2-hour observation

oral_ketamine.indications: Maintenance therapy, cost-effective, at-home use possible
advantages: Possible at-home use with proper monitoring

branch_outcomes.description: IV infusion protocol - gold standard for acute treatment
Contraindication present, refer to alternative treatments

steps.title: Pre-Treatment Education & Informed Consent
steps.description: Comprehensive patient education about ketamine therapy, expected effects, risks, benefits, treatment expectations, and obtaining detailed informed consent.
education_topics: Mechanism of action (NMDA receptor antagonist, rapid antidepressant)
Expected timeline of response (often within hours to days)
Dissociative effects during infusion (floating, detachment, perceptual changes)
Duration of effects (dissociation lasts ~2 hours, antidepressant effects days to weeks)
Treatment protocol (6 infusions over 2-4 weeks typically)
Need for maintenance (often required to sustain benefits)
Common side effects (dissociation, nausea, elevated BP)
Rare but serious risks (hypertensive crisis, emergence reactions, bladder toxicity with chronic use)
Post-infusion restrictions (no driving for 24 hours, responsible adult required)
Integration and psychotherapy to maximize benefits
informed_consent_elements: Off-label use (except Spravato which is FDA-approved)
Treatment agreement (no drug diversion, adherence to protocol)
practical_preparation: NPO guidelines: no food 4 hours before, clear liquids okay up to 2 hours before
Arrange ride home after each infusion
Bring music or playlist if desired (some patients prefer)
Clear schedule day of infusion (no work, no responsibilities)

steps.title: Ketamine Infusion Session 1
steps.description: First ketamine infusion session. Standard dose of 0.5 mg/kg IV over 40 minutes with continuous monitoring. Critical to establish tolerance, assess response, and refine protocol.

arrival_and_setup: Administer baseline scales (if first infusion or weekly check)
Monitoring equipment attached (BP cuff, pulse oximetry, telemetry if indicated)
pre_medications: Anti-nausea medication optional (ondansetron 4 mg IV if patient prone to nausea)
Anxiolytic rarely needed (benzodiazepine may reduce ketamine efficacy)

infusion_protocol.dose_calculation: 0.5 mg/kg based on actual body weight
infusion_protocol.preparation: Ketamine diluted in 50-100 mL normal saline
infusion_protocol.infusion_rate: Administered over 40 minutes via infusion pump
infusion_protocol.monitoring_location: Comfortable private room, low lighting, minimal stimulation

vitals_monitoring.frequency: Every 10 minutes during infusion and 30 minutes post-infusion

alert_parameters.systolic_bp: > 180 mmHg or increase >40 mmHg from baseline
alert_parameters.heart_rate: > 110 bpm or increase >30 bpm from baseline

hypertension: First line: reassurance, deep breathing, reducing stimulation
If persistent BP >180/110: slow or pause infusion
If severe or symptomatic: antihypertensive (labetalol 10-20 mg IV or hydralazine 10 mg IV)
Resume infusion at slower rate once BP controlled
management_if_elevated.tachycardia: Usually resolves spontaneously; beta-blocker rarely needed
management_if_elevated.respiratory_depression: Very rare at 0.5 mg/kg; stimulate patient, reduce infusion rate, have airway support available

dissociation_monitoring.scales: CADSS (Clinician-Administered Dissociative States Scale) - administered at 40 min and 80 min
patient_experience: Effects: floating sensation, detachment from body/surroundings, visual distortions, time distortion, dreamlike state

clinician_presence: Mental health clinician checks in periodically
managing_distress: Verbal reassurance: 'You're safe, this is temporary, you're doing great'
Grounding techniques if needed: touch, orientation to reality
Rarely: slow infusion if severe distress
Very rarely: benzodiazepine rescue (impairs antidepressant effect, avoid if possible)

post_infusion_monitoring.vitals: Every 15-30 minutes until stable and near baseline
post_infusion_monitoring.dissociation_resolution: Patient should be alert, oriented, communicative before discharge
discharge_criteria: Vital signs stable and near baseline
Dissociative effects resolved (can walk, talk normally)
Responsible adult present to drive patient home

post_infusion_instructions: Rest at home for remainder of day
No driving or operating machinery for 24 hours
Call clinic if severe headache, persistent nausea, chest pain, concerning symptoms

steps.title: Ketamine Infusion Sessions 2-3 (Week 1)
steps.description: Second and third infusion sessions, typically scheduled 2-4 days apart during first week. Same protocol as Session 1 with ongoing assessment of tolerability and early response.

pre_infusion_check_in: How did you feel after last infusion?
Side effects or concerns from previous infusion?
session_structure.infusion_protocol: Same as Session 1: 0.5 mg/kg over 40 minutes
session_structure.vitals_monitoring: Every 10 minutes during infusion, every 15-30 minutes for 90 min post-infusion

response_monitoring.early_responders: Some patients notice mood improvement within 24-72 hours of first or second infusion
response_monitoring.typical_timeline: Most patients begin noticing effects after 2-4 infusions
response_monitoring.suicidal_ideation: Often rapid reduction in suicidal thoughts (within hours to days)
response_monitoring.energy_and_motivation: May increase before mood fully lifts

dose_adjustments.if_minimal_dissociation_session_1: May consider increasing to 0.6-0.75 mg/kg for subsequent sessions
dose_adjustments.if_excessive_distress_session_1: May decrease to 0.4 mg/kg or slow infusion rate
dose_adjustments.if_bp_very_elevated: May need antihypertensive pre-treatment or dose reduction
dose_adjustments.standard_approach: Most patients continue 0.5 mg/kg for all sessions

steps.title: Ketamine Infusion Sessions 4-6 (Weeks 2-3)
steps.description: Completion of acute treatment phase with infusions 4, 5, and 6. Scheduled 2-3 times per week. Assessment of cumulative response and planning for maintenance.

weekly_assessments: Administer PHQ-9, GAD-7 weekly (typically before Session 4)
session_structure.infusion_protocol: Continue same dose (typically 0.5 mg/kg over 40 minutes)
session_structure.cumulative_effects: Antidepressant response typically builds with each infusion
session_structure.patient_education: Discuss maintenance planning, duration of effects, relapse prevention

response_patterns.suicidal_ideation: Often dramatic reduction even in partial responders

steps.title: End of Acute Phase Assessment (Week 3-4)
steps.description: Comprehensive assessment after completing 6 infusions to evaluate treatment response and determine next steps (maintenance, additional acute infusions, or alternative treatments).

symptom_response: Percentage improvement in MADRS or PHQ-9

steps.title: Treatment Response Evaluation & Maintenance Planning
steps.description: Clinical decision-making based on response to acute ketamine treatment. Determine need for maintenance infusions, frequency, and duration of continued treatment.

response_categories.maintenance_frequency: Start with infusions every 2-4 weeks, titrate to individual need

response_categories.recommendation: Consider additional acute infusions, increase dose, or add adjunctive therapy

standard_approach.titration_strategy: Increase interval gradually if sustained response; decrease if symptoms return
typical_patterns: Some patients stable on monthly infusions
standard_approach.duration: Often 6-12 months, some patients require indefinite maintenance
standard_approach.goal: Find minimum frequency that maintains response

relapse_prevention: Continue concurrent antidepressants (may provide additive benefit)
Early intervention if symptoms begin to return (bring infusion forward)
Lifestyle factors (sleep, exercise, stress management, social connection)

factors_affecting_maintenance_need: Severity of baseline depression (more severe → longer maintenance)
Duration of current episode (longer episode → longer maintenance)
Number of prior episodes (recurrent depression → longer maintenance)

discontinuation_considerations.appropriate_timing: After sustained remission for 6-12 months with good life circumstances
discontinuation_considerations.monitoring: Close follow-up for early signs of relapse
discontinuation_considerations.relapse_management: Resume infusions at previous effective frequency

branch_outcomes.description: Patient responded, begin maintenance infusion protocol
Partial response, continue with additional infusions

steps.title: Maintenance Ketamine Infusions
steps.description: Ongoing ketamine infusions at individualized intervals to maintain antidepressant response. Typically every 2-4 weeks initially, adjusted based on symptom trajectory.

maintenance_structure.infusion_protocol: Same as acute phase: 0.5 mg/kg over 40 minutes (unless dose was adjusted)

monitoring.vitals: Every 10 minutes during infusion as in acute phase
monitoring.scales: PHQ-9 and GAD-7 before each infusion; MADRS monthly
monitoring.functional_status: Sheehan Disability Scale monthly or quarterly

interval_adjustment.if_symptoms_returning_before_scheduled_i: Decrease interval (e.g., from 4 weeks to 3 weeks)
interval_adjustment.if_sustained_remission_well_past_schedul: Cautiously increase interval (e.g., from 3 weeks to 4 weeks)
interval_adjustment.goal: Find longest interval that maintains remission

bladder_health.concern: Chronic ketamine use can cause bladder toxicity (ketamine cystitis)
bladder_health.risk: Much lower with therapeutic dosing vs. recreational abuse, but monitor
screening: Ask about urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, pain, hematuria) at each visit
If symptoms develop: urology referral, urinalysis, consider cystoscopy
May need to discontinue ketamine if cystitis develops

cognitive_function.concern: Chronic ketamine might affect memory or cognition
cognitive_function.monitoring: Subjective assessment; formal neuropsych testing if concerns arise
cognitive_function.evidence: Limited data on long-term therapeutic ketamine; most studies reassuring

monitoring: Signs of misuse (requesting early refills, seeking ketamine from other sources)
Preoccupation with dissociative effects rather than antidepressant effects
Urine drug screens periodically if concerns
abuse_potential.red_flags: If abuse suspected, discontinue and refer to addiction treatment

cardiovascular.monitoring: Baseline ECG annually; more frequent if concerns
cardiovascular.blood_pressure: Check at each infusion; ensure home BP remains controlled

hepatic_function.monitoring: LFTs every 6-12 months (ketamine metabolized by liver)

psychotherapy: CBT, DBT, or other evidence-based therapy
Integration work (processing insights from dissociative experiences)
medications: Ketamine may allow reduction of other medications in some cases
Avoid benzodiazepines if possible (may impair ketamine efficacy)

assessments: Bladder symptom screening at each visit

long_term_outcomes.durability: Many patients maintain response for months to years with maintenance infusions
long_term_outcomes.quality_of_life: Often significant improvement in functioning and life satisfaction
long_term_outcomes.safety: Generally well-tolerated long-term at therapeutic doses

absolute_contraindications: Recent MI, stroke, or unstable angina (<6 months)

adverse_effects_monitoring.management: Usually mild; slow infusion or antihypertensive if severe
Benzodiazepine, supportive care, monitor until resolved

adverse_effects_monitoring.frequency: Rare with therapeutic use (<1%), more common with chronic abuse
Unclear; likely rare with therapeutic dosing
adverse_effects_monitoring.management: Monitor subjectively; neuropsych testing if concerns; consider discontinuation

adverse_effects_monitoring.frequency: Low in monitored therapeutic setting (<5%), higher in vulnerable individuals
adverse_effects_monitoring.management: Screen carefully, monitor for signs, discontinue if misuse

emergency_protocols.hypertensive_crisis: BP >200/120 or symptomatic: stop infusion, IV antihypertensive (labetalol, hydralazine), cardiology consult, transfer if unstable
emergency_protocols.severe_emergence_reaction: Benzodiazepine (lorazepam 1-2 mg IV/IM), supportive care, monitor until resolved, psychiatry consult
emergency_protocols.cardiovascular_event: Chest pain, arrhythmia: stop infusion, ECG, cardiac monitoring, emergency medicine/cardiology consult, transfer if needed
emergency_protocols.respiratory_depression: Very rare at 0.5 mg/kg but monitor: stimulate patient, supplemental O2, airway support, stop infusion
emergency_protocols.severe_psychotic_reaction: Benzodiazepine, antipsychotic if needed, psychiatry consult, possible hospitalization

considerations: Higher cardiovascular risk - thorough cardiac clearance
May be more sensitive to dissociative effects
May still be beneficial for bipolar depression
Consider lower dose or slower infusion
Ketamine shows promise for PTSD in addition to depression
Dissociative effects may be triggering for some trauma survivors
Require careful screening and ongoing monitoring
Intranasal or oral formulations have higher abuse potential than supervised IV

integration_and_psychotherapy.importance: Ketamine should not be standalone treatment; psychotherapy integration enhances and sustains outcomes
recommended_approaches: Ketamine-Assisted Psychotherapy (KAP): Psychotherapy sessions before, during, and after infusions
Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT): Values-based living
Psychodynamic therapy: Processing insights from dissociative experiences

integration_sessions.timing: Within 1-2 days after each infusion ideally
focus: Processing dissociative experience and any insights
Addressing emotions or content that arose
Building on momentum of improved mood

iv_ketamine.insurance: Often not covered (off-label); improving with more evidence

intranasal_esketamine.insurance: Better coverage (FDA-approved) but often requires prior authorization
intranasal_esketamine.REMS_requirements: Must be administered in certified clinic with observation

access_barriers: Limited number of providers offering ketamine

clinical_pearls: Ketamine provides rapid relief often within hours to days - transformative for suicidal patients
Most robust evidence for treatment-resistant depression, but also used for other indications
Dissociation is part of the therapeutic effect - don't try to eliminate it
Blood pressure elevation is expected and usually mild - monitor but don't overreact
Maintenance is almost always needed - plan for long-term treatment
Integration therapy maximizes and sustains benefits - ketamine alone is not enough
Screen carefully for abuse potential - rare in monitored settings but real risk
Not a cure - it's a tool to provide symptom relief and window for therapeutic work
Works best as part of comprehensive treatment plan (therapy, lifestyle, support)
